item.title: Hamas Needed a New Way to Get Money From Iran. It Turned to Crypto.
item.description: The pivot to digital currencies helped Hamas receive large sums from Iran in the two years preceding the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel.

item.title: Oregon Decriminalized Hard Drugs. It Isn't Working.
item.description: A majority of voters now want to undo a pioneering change as public drug use has become rampant.

item.description: It&#x27;s just one piece in what may be the most complicated kidnapping crisis in modern history. Inside the search for Bipin Joshi.

item.title: Your 401(k) Is Falling Behind. Here's What You Should Do.
item.description: How to know when it is time to take your portfolio off autopilot.

item.title: Speaker Johnson Unveils GOP's Plan to Ward Off Government Shutdown
item.description: The Republican proposal would extend funding into early next year.

item.title: Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital Goes Dark at Center of Israel-Hamas Battle Zone
item.description: Thousands remain in the complex that has become a focus of Israeli invasion.

item.title: Michigan Beats Penn State Without Jim Harbaugh While Legal Battle Ramps Up
item.description: The school couldn’t immediately block Harbaugh’s suspension over an alleged sign-stealing operation hours before a Saturday noon showdown—but will get a hearing ahead of next weekend’s Maryland game.

item.title: Pope Francis Fires Conservative U.S. Bishop
item.description: Bishop Joseph Strickland, one of the pope’s most vocal critics in the U.S. hierarchy, was relieved of the pastoral governance of the Diocese of Tyler, Texas.

item.title: Key Witness at Sam Bankman-Fried Trial to Launch New Crypto Exchange
item.description: Ex-FTX lawyer Can Sun and other former company executives want the new exchange to allow customers to verify holdings at any time.

item.title: Iran's President Joins Saudi Summit, Criticizes U.S. Support for Israel
item.description: Iran’s president joined dozens of Arab and Muslim leaders at a summit in Saudi Arabia—the first such visit to the kingdom in more than 15 years—as the Islamic world sought to project unified opposition to Israel’s military operations in Gaza.

item.title: He Has Been Crazy About Cars His Whole Life. In Retirement, That Hasn't Changed.
item.description: Peter Volny found retirement boring. Until, that is, he hosted a car show.

item.title: As Migrants Keep Coming, El Paso Spends Millions to Keep Them Off the Streets
item.description: Record numbers of migrant families overwhelm nonprofits and camp downtown, prompting the city to spend $3.8 million for its first public shelter.

item.title: A Pond in Hawaii Turns Pink and More
item.description: Pandas have their last day at the Washington, D.C., zoo, a Hawaii pond turns pink, abortion rights supporters celebrate a victory in Ohio and more top images of the week.

item.title: Ordinary Russians Feel Wrath of Putin's Repression
item.description: The Kremlin’s crackdown on opposition to the war in Ukraine is targeting thousands of everyday citizens in addition to well-known politicians, activists and journalists.

item.title: Killing Federal Agencies Is Easier Said Than Done
item.description: Republican presidential candidates want to eliminate government agencies such as the Education Department, but Congress would likely stand in the way.

item.title: How Chipotle's Founder Is Moving Beyond Burritos
item.description: Steve Ells returns to the restaurant industry with a new concept light on meat and long on automation.

item.title: Microsoft's Chris Young on Bringing AI to Main Street
item.description: The top strategy executive views nontech customers as artificial intelligence’s big untapped market.

item.title: The Militia at the Center of the Darfur Genocide Kills Hundreds in Sudan
item.description: A paramilitary group that grew from the infamous Janjaweed militia has been blamed for the killing of about 800 people, mostly boys and men, in a Darfur refugee camp.
